title: This Video Will Make You Angry

options.label: B
options.text: By targeting emotions

options.label: C
options.text: By using logic

options.label: D

options.text: They get more attention, but not necessarily more accuracy

options.label: C
options.text: They get less attention, but more accuracy

options.label: B

title: Why you think you're right — even if you're wrong

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary difference between the "soldier mindset" and the "scout mindset"?

options.label: A
options.text: The soldier mindset is focused on defending one's own ideas, while the scout mindset is focused on understanding the facts.

options.label: B
options.text: The soldier mindset is driven by emotions like defensiveness, while the scout mindset is driven by emotions like curiosity.

options.label: C
options.text: The soldier mindset is concerned with winning arguments, while the scout mindset is concerned with seeking the truth.

options.label: D
options.text: The soldier mindset is rooted in logic and reason, while the scout mindset is rooted in emotions and intuition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the case of Alfred Dreyfus an example of?

options.label: A
options.text: A case of mistaken identity, where an innocent man was wrongly accused and convicted.

options.label: B
options.text: A case of motivated reasoning, where unconscious biases and desires influenced the interpretation of evidence.

options.label: C
options.text: A case of conspiracy, where a group of people worked together to frame an innocent man.

options.label: D
options.text: A case of judicial error, where the legal system failed to provide a fair trial.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the characteristics of people with a "scout mindset"?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more likely to feel defensive when confronted with contradictory information, and are more likely to change their minds based on emotions rather than evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to feel curious and intrigued when learning new information, and are more likely to test their own beliefs and values.

options.label: C
options.text: They are more likely to be grounded and confident in their self-worth, and are less likely to feel threatened by contradictory information.

options.label: D
options.text: They are more likely to be rigid and inflexible in their thinking, and are more likely to resist changing their minds based on new evidence.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key takeaway about the characteristics of people with a "scout mindset"?

options.label: A
options.text: They are primarily driven by logic and reason, and are less influenced by emotions and intuition.

options.label: B
options.text: They are primarily driven by emotions like curiosity and intrigue, and are less influenced by logic and reason.

options.label: C
options.text: They are primarily driven by a desire to win arguments and defend their own ideas, and are less influenced by a desire to seek the truth.

options.label: D
options.text: They are primarily driven by a desire to feel proud and confident in their self-worth, and are less influenced by a desire to learn and grow.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary thing that individuals and societies need to improve their judgment?

options.label: A
options.text: More instruction in logic, rhetoric, and probability.

options.label: B
options.text: A greater emphasis on critical thinking and analytical skills.

options.label: C
options.text: A change in the way people feel, specifically a shift towards a "scout mindset" that is driven by emotions like curiosity and intrigue.

options.label: D
options.text: A greater emphasis on moral character and personal values.

title: Don't eat the marshmallow!
